Title: A Randomised Controlled Trial on Remote Expert Instructional Feedback in Endovascular Simulation-Based Education

Background: This randomised controlled trial evaluates the effectiveness of remote expert instructional feedback in endovascular simulation-based education, aiming to increase training opportunities for vascular surgery residents.

Methods: Conducted at the RCSI Simulation Centre, the study involved 12 vascular surgery residents in Ireland, ranging from second to seventh year of residency. Participants were randomly assigned to two groups: Group 1 received in-person feedback first, followed by remote feedback, while Group 2 received remote feedback first, followed by in-person feedback. The primary outcome was the effectiveness of remote feedback, assessed through interviews and a validated questionnaire post-training. Randomisation was achieved through a crossover design, and allocation concealment was not specified. Blinding was not implemented for participants or outcome assessors.

Results: The questionnaire results showed no significant difference between remote and in-person feedback. Interviews revealed mixed feelings about remote feedback, but participants reported no limiting factors to practice. Clear communication and shared task understanding were critical for successful remote feedback. No adverse events were reported during the study.

Interpretation: Remote expert feedback is a feasible and effective method for endovascular skills training, providing increased practice opportunities for vascular surgery residents. The study underscores the importance of effective communication in remote learning environments and suggests that remote feedback can complement traditional in-person training.

Trial registration: Not provided.

Funding: Not specified.
